Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: American Innovations in an Age of Discovery: Teaching Science and Engineering through 3D-printed Historical Reconstructions

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Advanced manufacturing technologies, such as 3D printing, are transforming design and several fields of engineering. This innovative project will use 3D technology to help students learn about science and engineering through the history of inventions in the United States. As part of science and engineering classes, middle and high-school students will use 3D printing technology to recreate historically significant inventions, using digitized versions from the Smithsonian Institution (e.g., the Wright brothers' airplane - http://3d.si.edu). The project will create modules that will connect these significant inventions from the past with contemporary technologies, science, and engineering. Student teamwork will help participants understand the collaborative process of invention. The project will develop supporting materials for middle school science and engineering teachers. This project will advance efforts of the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program to better understand and promote practices that increase students' motivations and capacities to pursue careers in fields of science, technology, engineering, or mathematics (STEM).

The module development will address calls in recent national reports and standards for the integration of engineering in science teaching and learning. The research questions and data collection/analysis will examine how the modules impact student knowledge of the concepts and if teachers can successfully implement them in classrooms. Data to be collected include students' work on the modules, interviews and focus groups with students, interviews with teachers, and classroom observation. Using comparison classrooms, the study will also use pre-tests and post-tests of students' content knowledge to understand the impact of the modules in the treatment classrooms on students' knowledge of science and engineering. The goal will be to document the impact of the modules on students' learning in science and engineering courses and to understand how historical inventions can be used to engage students in how scientific and engineering innovation happen. The implementation will include school districts with diverse populations of students in two states, providing a range of test sites for the materials.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the course of the award period, the National Museum of American History (NMAH), the Smithsonian Digital Projects Office, and University of Virginia (UVA) collaborated to create a series of maker kits complete with animations, 3D models, object tours, and videos for science history to be more accesible for educators and students by helping it come alive through making. 

NMAH partnered with UVA by using objects in its collection that are aligned with UVA's make-to-learn kits. NMAH provided CAD animations of early inventions for students to see and understand fundemental innovations on which current technology is built. Inventions include: 

  • Davenport Motor
  • Morse Telegraph Key
  • Pixii Generator
  • Pole Reverser
  • Power Grid (transformer)
  • Telegraph Network
  • Telephone Relay
  • Telegraph Sounder
  • Telephone Network (Vacuum Tube)
  • Trough Battery

The three kits are available here:

  • https://3d.si.edu/education/battery-linear-motor
  • https://3d.si.edu/education/telegraph-key
  • https://3d.si.edu/education/speaker-and-generator

In addition to these CAD animations, NMAH created 3D models and object tours of the Davenport motor, telephone, and speaker. We worked with a historian from Princeton to provide historical context and a bibliography for these objects. These models and tours are available here:

  • https://3d.si.edu/education/motor
  • https://3d.si.edu/education/telegraph
  • https://3d.si.edu/education/speaker

Videos were also produced to provide other points of access for educators and students into science history. Examples of these videos include:

  • American Innovations in an Age of Discovery (project overview): https://vimeo.com/190266874/a9c0bf1f7d
  • Age of Discovery (electricity and magnetism): https://vimeo.com/217076158/4ff7632709
  • Age of Electrical Communications: Telegraph: https://vimeo.com/217076779/21e0864d24
  • Age of Electrical Communications: Telephone: https://vimeo.com/217076824/5f7d4742a4
  • Age of Power: Electric Motor:
    https://vimeo.com/217076685/57eb7e7305

Throughout the entire process, we consulted with educators and students in Texas, South Carolina, and Virginia in partnership with UVA. The input and feedack from these educators and students was incoporated in multiple iterations of the project. NMAH hosted students from Virginia schools to showcase the inventions they designed using the maker kits in our Spark!Lab space.

NMAH appreciates the NSF's support for this important work that makes science history more accessible to students across the country.
